@kacy Lockify is for individuals and businesses. Individuals = distribution; Business=revenue model.

@kacy XMPP does have encryption (and many sites have HTTPS), BUT that 1.) only works when the other user is on a secure connection as well and 2.) doesn't protect data at rest, only in transit. Lockify works across any communication channels and secures data in flight and at rest.

Regarding "too many steps" keep in mind that we demo'ed a single auth method - our phone based one - other methods usually have fewer steps. Also, we're always thrilled to hear ideas about how to further simplify any aspect of Lockify.
@Humancell Lockify offers both client and server-side encryption - plaintext is never stored on the server.
jtemplin@lockify.com
Hi All - Jack from Lockify here - sorry for the delayed responses and thanks for your interest/smart comments - it's been a whirlwind for us since LAUNCH
@jake_gold Yes, attachments can be encrypted locally or on the server - depending on your preferences and file size.
@nicholasserra Good point. We actually encourage people who use Gmail as their auth method to use another channel to send the link.
@leah Agreed about the Gmail plugin! It's on the Lockify roadmap!
What an awesome bunch of comments/questions. If any of you want early access to the private beta - just get me your email address - we'd love more feedback from this crew. Thanks!
@jtemplin Good point. Thanks for addressing that. I wish you the best of luck! :-)
Cool meeting you guys at the event.
Interesting idea. who are the main competitors?
